posts.name: Ian McTavish
posts.cooked: I’m curious to know the experiences that teams had using the PDP 2.0.  We are exploring the pros/cons of power management.  The PDH has served us very well and we’ve been happy with it.  We have found that it is difficult to get 4awg from our battery into the PDH and were wondering if that was easier on the PDP 2.0.

posts.name: Brian Rozmierski
posts.cooked:
As a CSA , this is pretty much the only FRC product I have on my Actively Discourage / Do Not Recommend list, and I admit, I’m pretty vocal about it.

Predictably, I had a team this year ask for help with a brown out problem and we were unable to get current information from their logging because they had the PDP 2.0 and did not have a logging framework set up, nor were they logging currents from their motor controllers.

After checking connections, batteries, etc, we had to check motor controllers one at a time, running motors in the pits for a few minutes. As we didn’t want to risk getting a logging framework up and running (they were tight on RAM too on the RoboRio 1). Eventually found a problem Neo 1.1 that was drawing far to much current. (Motor swap fixed their issue.)

What would have been about 90s to identify from “hello” became almost 30 minutes as we looked to try to find ways to get the data to guide our next steps. They nearly missed their next match.

If you think you really need some feature the PDH 2.0 has, make sure you set time aside with your programming team to ensure you capture that information you’re going to miss out on. Maybe you won’t need it… maybe you will. Just don’t forget Murphy’s Law.

bdaroz:

If you think you really need some feature the PDH 2.0 has

Which you probably don’t, unless you must have 21 or 22 motors. You can do up to 20 with the PDH and although the PDP 2.0 has 24 high current channels 2 of them have to be used for the RIO and radio.

posts.name: Ian McTavish
posts.cooked: Thanks, this is good food for thought. We do implement logging so aren’t too worried but it is definitely something to think about.

posts.name: Ian McTavish
posts.cooked:
For me there are two key features I am intrigued by: We use 4awg wires from batteries, the PDP seems like they will fit better reducing this as a major potential failure point.

The increased efficiency is key as we try to milk every last amp.

To be honest more ports isn’t a key factor as it goes against  our goal of reducing DOF and with brushless motors there is less need to add more motors to a gearbox.

The PDH has been stellar for us but fitting 4awg wires in has been challenging.

posts.name: Jade
posts.cooked: Note if your using all CTRE motor controllers CTRE makes this super easy, just plug in a USB drive and call SignalLogger.start() .

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
bdaroz:

If you think you really need some feature the PDH 2.0 has

We love the lug based main power inputs.

bdaroz:

became almost 30 minutes as we looked to try to find ways to get the data

Phoenix Tuner graphs are a sub two minute solution on our robots. Rev tuner should be equivalent. If you don’t have Smart motor controllers, you shouldn’t use PDP 2.0.

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked:
As with the original PDP , the WAGO terminals on the PDP2 are difficult to operate (even with the sold-separately Official WAGO Bent Screwdriver™).  Power distribution always seems to end up in a tight location where it’s hard enough to get wires in, much less have the clearance to swing the tool around above the entire unit.  With the number of times we reconfigured circuits last year, having easy to use lever terminals on the PDH was something we appreciated a lot.

I also sympathize with CSAs on the loss of “Level 1” built-in logging.  I’m all for reducing cost of components, but this seems like a lot of lost utility for a small cost savings.

In our experience, getting 4AWG into the PDH main terminals is definitely possible, just requires a bit of care.  Make sure you get the strip length right, and insert the wire smoothly, ideally in one go.  If it gets crumpled, it’s not going to go well.

posts.name: M
posts.cooked: Hated taking out wires with how tight the tolerances were couldn’t fit a screwdriver in so glad to have a PDH hopefully next year over PDP 1

posts.name: iair pablo tarlovsky
posts.cooked: Does anyone have experience with inserting 2 AWG power cables into the PDP 2?
